item.title: Financial independence / retire early — 37 replies — 148.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Financial independence / retire early

Open thread • Replies: 37 • Updated: 2026-02-23 16:58 UTC

OP

How's FIRE going for you, anons?

Early replies (first 3)

61884964
>>61884958
Well I'm looking into LCOL countries I can retire to because waiting until I'm a multi millionaire in the states is not viable.

61884966
>>61884958
Just need a 7x then I'm good. Already have rope if ready if I don't reach the goal in 5 years

61884967
>>61884958
i have about 3m networth but haven't quit my job yet. making too much money but want to quit real bad. i took a 4 day weekend recently and got bored because i have no life and hobbies because my job dominates my life and i have no energy left over to develop my personal life after work.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61884983
>>61884958
I'm back to ramen noodle mode.
I WILL make this savings last until I get a job again.

61884986
>>61884958
I'm just living off NEETbux+savings. It doesn't completely cover rent, so once my savings are gone I'm going to just KYS myself.

61884996
>>61884974
Interesting. I never thought of Japan as having a low cost of living. And I've heard Thailand is not as cheap as it was.

61884999
>>61884976
>>61884986
I listened to a Grant Cardone video on YouTube about pulling IRA retirement money into self-directed fund then you can use it to buy real estate without getting the penalty but you have to go big and do multi-dwelling unit or else IRS flags you. I'm too chicken shit to try it (yet) but if you're going to an hero anyway fuck it try it
>pull life retirement savings
>buy 10 unit apartment building
>give self job fixing toilets
>collect rent from tenants
>profit

61885003
ok maybe a 3 unit building

61885030
>>61884999
You literally cannot fix the toilets yourself. Under IRC §4975 you are considered a "disqualified" person. Basically you can own it but you can never touch it. Very gay way to 'own' something.

61885054
way ahead of schedule.
>Full time job income (104K + 11K in retirement)
>Cost of living 32K
>Fully owned apartment(450K)
>308K in liquidish assets
>90K in retirement
>2K coming in every month from passive revenue from a side business (vidya gaems)
In 7-8 years i will probably reach full FIRE. But i'm releasing new products this year. If i can have similar success i will probably just Barista FIRE living the gamedev dream.

61885059
>>61884967
Dude, just quit. You'll probably decompress after a month or two, then you can re-evaluate. If you decide you need to work, then you can just go apply to some jobs. Maybe you'll decide you want to work in a library or something stupid like that.

61885062
>>61885030
that fucking sucks what is Cardone talking about then?
retirement money is just going to the bank then when I starve to death. maybe that was their plan all along.
take the 10% penalty + taxes ? now it's a duplex maybe in a cold flyover state

61885102
Just had my 2nd kid.
Already gave up and accepted that I'll be waging til I die.

61885131
>>61884958
Pretty good despite the recent market drawdown. I stopped working 9 months ago and moved to a luxury condo in Thailand. Expenses are relatively low but I'm still paying my mortgage and car note in America. I get a little bit of income from trading options and renting out my house to my younger sister. I'm financially set for the rest of my life but I'm still figuring out what I want to do as far as family, kids, etc.

61885135
>>61885062
>>61885030
>>61884986

ok I found this. instead of self directed IRA to have to roll it into a business startup
so don't an hero yet
or put me down as your beneficiary first

https://www.bankrate.com/loans/small-business/what-are-robs/#:~:text=Key%20takeaways,penalties%20are%20associated%20with%20ROBS.

61885141
>>61884967
Nigger. Based on the 4% rule you can draw about 120k yearly off investments and statistically never run out of money. Wife and I retired early w/ Lite Fire. No debt. Last year our gross income was $55,000. We bought and sold a RV, Saw the Grand Canyon, Zion, Bryce Canyon, Rushmore. Took a 21 day cruise from west coast through Panama Canal, Cruised out of Florida for 3 weeks and hung out in Fort Lauderdale for 2. Did 2 more week in the Caribbean. Have a 20 day transatlantic cruise from NYC to Sicily booked with stops in 9 ports in April. Tons of midweek short trips seeing cool shit. Leaving work is an adjustment definitely but I have never been happier. See the world, meet people, always with an eye to relocation. Picrel is heading into Cartagena Columbia.

61885152
>>61884967
I was just like you before I decided to walk away. I call it "golden handcuffs" when a job pays so well that it makes you feel obligated to keep going even though you don't need the money. Your job feels like your identity but I promise you'll forget about it after you quit and find new hobbies and a gf.

61887260
>>61884974
>>61884996
Japan is not a lcol area. Its cheaper compared to the west but not Thailand/Vietnam cheap. My plan is to live 90 days visa free there a year and live frugally elsewhere for the rest of the year.

61887270
>>61884958
Closing in on luxury fat FIRE thanks to gold/silver/oil/uranium. Fuck crypto.

61887292
I don't want to retire early, cuz id probably just be doing the same thing without getting paid for it, but i have enough money to be comfortable for now

61887302
I am starting to realize the whole game plan of FIRE is just giving me reason to wake up in the morning, something to look forward to. I dont think I will really be that much happier once I achieve my dream of semi financial freedom.

61887313
>>61887292
>id probably just be doing the same thing without getting paid for it
Your job is your hobby? Congrats. What do you do?

61887338
It's not really going.
Would take me getting my inheritance and buying the bottom of the next global market crash and riding the recovery wave with everything I can throw in during it.

61887601
uhh im 38. been retired since 32. probably unretiring soon.

61887625
>>61887313
gay prostitute

61890044
>>61887302
frugality is like a game, to see how little i can spend each month

61890071
>>61885054
what's your side business anon? reseller?

61890085
is 1.5M too little to retire?

I round tripped 8 figs being greedy
its all i have left

61890089
>>61890085
depends where you live

61890151
>>61885102
My #2 is 4 months old now. Thanks to the fire-induced frugality I was able to reduce my hours for half a year by 10 hours a week which was priceless in itself. Will probably also wage forever but probably only 20 hours or so per week.

>>61884958
We managed to pay off the house @32. other than that I only have 15k cash and 50k in the MSCI.
The plan was to retire @40 but unrealistic unless I win the lottery ( and I don't even play)
So yes full fire is impossible right now, but on the plus side: we need less than 2k/ month for a very comfortable life.
I'm converting a part of the house to a rental flat atm which should bring another 600 per month and allow for tax deductions.
After installing solar this year my electricity bill should drop from 110 to 40 per month.

So all in all we can have a cozy lifestyle for an acceptable trade off in lifetime.
Wife would like to work 20 hours/week in 10 years or so, I should be able to fully switch to do freelance consultant work in my niche ( or not. Her meager wage combined with the surplus of the next 10 years should easily pay for everything and give the kids a nice tailwind)

I'm putting 180 bucks/month per kind into an ETF which should become a nice 150k downpayment (infl.adj.) when they turn 27

61890181
Never gonna happen on my income. Millennials are fucked out of retirement. At least I own all my shit and have actual children and a loyal wife.

61890213
I dont know what number to stop at..

61891226
>>61884968
Balkan and Baltic countries are cheap and super white.

Fuck off if you're not white though. They're the most racist countries and that's what makes them awesome.

61887589

61887591
>>61887589
LUCKYYY!

61887799
>>61887123
Not according to Yonotan, who's answer is
>Kaspa full nodes verify only recent history, because the goal of Consensus is to reach Agreement, not to print a medal of historical aesthetic integrity that satisfies the aesthetic tastes of cryptographers with no tangible integrity value to speak of.
TL;DR stop noticing

61887812
>>61887799
So who got 52% and reorganised blocks then? Which wallets?
Dumb fag

TL;DR: block chains are vulnerable to 51% attacks Jeetish FUD

61887838
>>61887812
>why worry about something that isn't going to happen?
Fact is, there is no full chain history and the implications of that are still unknown. Maybe it's nothing, maybe it's going to be devastating in the future. We just don't know

61887853
Honestly I like this shit. And I made money on it last year buying in hard at 5 cents and holding until 12 cents.

The tech is good - it’s magic to watch hard wallet confirmations happen instantly. The chart still looks painful though, but I’m actively considering starting to acquire again. It’s a spiffy first party wallet to be honest.

Any word on level 2 shit?

61887873
>>61887799
Yonatan here, this is misleading.

Kaspa supports archival nodes and pruned nodes. Bitcoin, Ethereum and most modern Blockchain also prune.
So this is not unique to Kaspa.

The most important distinction you need to realise is that pruning old block data does NOT mean skipping consensus verification. Nodes still validate consensus, enforce rules and track UTXO state. They just don't keep every ancient block at once.

61887902
>>61887873
As we've established, Mr Sompolinsky, it's not that the old blocks weren't kept; they were lost. And a great deal of work has been done to recover what has been lost, but not all of it has been recovered.

61888092

61888189

>>61885700
7 and maybe 0 if she’s a squirter

61888292
>>61885700

61888770
>>61885700

61889128
>>61885700
7 and 9, that's it

61891242
>>61885700

item.title: European funds for an american — 15 replies — 60.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
European funds for an american

Open thread • Replies: 15 • Updated: 2026-02-23 17:01 UTC

OP

I want to put 20% of my account in foreign, but not all foreign is created equal.

I predicted the rise in the polish economy. It's very simple, a homogenous white country free from communism is always going to become rich. A diverse country full of communists like Canada and South Africa is going to get worse and worse.

I also predicted that the real-estate market in Croatia would sky rocket due to whites fleeing countries like the UK. I was right.

So.... are there any good mutual/index funds that target the white regions of Europe, that an American can invest in? Is there a Balkans fund? A Baltic fund? Norway/Finland fund (not Sweden or Denmark)? I do not want to invest in the UK, France, Germany, or Spain.

Early replies (first 3)

61890485
>finland
>white

61890499
>please buy my bag
nein. Death to every communist, that includes every single member of a political party, everyone over 50, every bureaucrat and every single subsidized "private" which in europe is every company.

61890518
No fucking way those numbers on finland are right. I live in Helsinki and it’s like 25% brown.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61890524
>>61890472
You are correct about Poland but everybody knew and knows about Poland but nobody wants to talk about why they've been the hottest economy in Europe for 15 years (white and Christian).

Anyway. You've never heard of EPOL?
I've owned the Polish index tracker ETFs for 8 years and it has done nicely.

Otherwise, Baltics do have stock markets but they are Frontier markets (this is below emerging markets) and you basically can't buy them if you're not in the country.

Norway invests in U.S. stocks. So does Sweden and their banks. Hottest Swedish bank stock is 100% invested in NYSE traded companies. So it's circular. If you invest in European banks or Norway you're actually buying U.S. stocks with extra steps. EPOL is heavily weighted towards Polish banks and you guessed it - they all hold U.S. company stocks.

European Bank customers are just a source of capital to invest in the New York Stock Exchange. And I'm an insider so I know.

If you want an actual good EU based investment buy WDEF. European defense spending will be hot for 15 years. Otherwise buy Spotify and the upcoming revolut IPO.

61890543
>>61890524
Any funds for manufacturing from the regions I mentioned in the OP, or medical services?
Medical services will always be the last to go even under socialism since Europeans will bankrupt their country with debt before they let a hospital go bankrupt.

61890855
>>61890543
You clearly don't understand the region. You're way out of your depth and element. I'm sorry but it would take me hours to explain this to you.
>t. American in Latvia who knows Poland pretty well (dated a Polish chick and been there many times).
You assume Eastern Europe has the economic model of America or Germany, just poorer and white. You're way off.

61890868
>>61890472
>France
>85%
lmaoooo
this is the 1972 census?

61890982
>>61890524
This map is from 10 or 15 years ago, it's actually changing rapidly now. Im from a small town and back then i haven't ever saw any foreign looking face apart from an occasional gypsy. Now we have filipino, indian, and central asian "guest" workers coming here to the middle of nowhere.

61890989
>>61890868
France is pretty much 100% white outside of Paris and the south

61891003
>>61890989
not at all. Even the smallest, most remote villages are chokefull of shitskins. There isn't a single STREET in the countryside not populated with at least 2-3 shitskins/niggers.
I know becuz i live in one.

61891134
>>61890472
>a homogenous white country free from communism
not Sweden

61891154
>>61890855
I have friends who moved to Croatia. Reason? White flight from the UK. Highly productive middle class white people pouring out of one area and into another, means good things for one economy and bad things for the other. It's no different than watching the small cities that surround Akron, Cleveland, Chicago, Detroit, Oakland, Baltimore, etc... All get richer and richer and have better and better economies due to all of the whites in those cities pouring out into the surrounding areas.

You say it's not that simple, yet I've told people this will happen and for 30 years, I've been right. I watched the real estate market in Croatia skyrocket into the stratosphere. I've also made a lot of money on real-estate outside of Cleveland and Akron just by investing in the white flight destinations.

61891164
>>61890868
This is in fact, old data.

>>61891134
Yes. That's why I said funds that invest in Norway and Finland, but not Denmark and Sweden. I know Finland isn't really Nordic but they're next door.

61891236
>>61891154
That's fine but from the average person's perspective you can't understand the bigger economic picture and appreciate the vast differences in market size and capital flows.
Life for average people may be more or less similar in Croatia and England but the English stock exchange is in another universe compared to these small economies.
As I said, I'm an American living in Latvia. My life is better in Latvia. I'm just a normal guy. The top 1% and .01% would see things quite differently. Where does one park $100,000,000 in the Baltics?
Answer: you don't. And downstream from that is YOU don't get to invest $50,000 in an Estonia market ETF either. These are frontier markets not even as developed as Brazil or India.

61891243
>>61891003
Euskadi

item.content:encoded:
Why not Start an Online Casino?

Open thread • Replies: 9 • Updated: 2026-02-23 17:02 UTC

OP

What exactly is stopping me?
>buy a license for $15k in XYZ island
>only take crypto to avoid KYC on burgerbros
>run some clean poker games
>collect money

Early replies (first 3)

61889851
>>61889846
Basad, be the cz killer!

61889853
Owning a casino is one way that putting all your profits back into it can go wrong.

61889866
How big is the crypto gambling audience even?

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61889869
>>61889846
I like your idea. But I find it hard to believe you just pay for your license and you’re free to do whatever you please. Prob too much red tape/ rules/regulations to. Can’t let the goyim get a step up at all.

You think you can get away with non KYC? I’m interested in hearing how

61889883
>>61889869
>you think you can get away with non-kyc?
There are already sites that are doing this operating in the US today. Ignition, ACR. and Coinpoker notably on the crypto side and WPT gold on the sweepstakes side. only coinpoker and WPT shill via ecelebs and in general US noncompliance sites seem like an underserved area of the market. I don’t get why there aren’t more players.

61889886
>>61889866
Considering GGPoker takes direct crypto deposits, it’s presumably massive.

61889896
Because the Australian government only allows poker machines. No poker or games outside of casinos, polymarket is banned. Online poker banned. Two up (coin flip game) is unbanned one day a year but banned for the rest of the year.

61890069
>>61889846
nothing, just need a few millions to start, and go through all the regulation hell

61891247
don’t you have hundreds of (thousands?) of competitors at this point

item.title: Redpil me on the Florida and Broader US Housing Market — 3 replies — 9.2/hr
item.content:encoded:
Redpil me on the Florida and Broader US Housing Market

Open thread • Replies: 3 • Updated: 2026-02-23 16:51 UTC

OP

> I'm an anon nearing 40, saved appropriately
> Finally at a stage to buy an investment property, ideally a condo / box in the sky
> Looking into Jupiter, Florida
> "Whoa, this condo was built after 2005, and the ask is $400K for 1200 square feet in a prime shopping area"
> Insurance comes out to $4-500 per month
> HOAs from $300-800 per month in this market
> Property taxes are eliminated?
> Cape Coral is literally a firesale
> Bake in a 8% vacancy rate
> Plus some maintenance
> I would have to charge $5,000 a month to break even? WTF

What is going on anons? What are you seeing out there? Would it be more prudent to invest in the Northeast (VT, NH, ME?) Is anyone doing okayish on investment income on a single family? What has been your experience?

Early replies (first 3)

61891143
>>61891078
As a shareholder I look down on landlord parasites. Invest in making people's lives better by providing a product/service, not holding people's living space hostage

61891189
>>61891078
You don't understand math or taxes which is why you're 40 and homeless

61891197
>>61891078

61890390
>What AI thinks
Argument That LINK Is a Security
Under the Howey test (SEC v. W.J. Howey Co.), an asset is a security if there is:
>An investment of money
>In a common enterprise
>With a reasonable expectation of profit
>Derived from the efforts of others
LINK can arguably meet all four elements:
>Investment of money:
People buy LINK with capital.
>Common enterprise:
The value of LINK rises and falls with the success of the Chainlink ecosystem.
>Expectation of profit:
Many buyers hold LINK expecting price appreciation, not immediate utility use.
>Efforts of others:
The value of LINK depends significantly on the continued development, partnerships, and ecosystem growth driven by Chainlink Labs.

Additionally, the original token distribution helped fund development, which resembles capital formation typical of securities offerings.

Thoughts anons? Is this class actionable?

item.title: Ai is about to crash the economy — 10 replies — 9.6/hr
item.content:encoded:
Ai is about to crash the economy

Open thread • Replies: 10 • Updated: 2026-02-23 16:07 UTC

OP

This was released today by citrini

AI gets good. Companies lay off workers. Margins expand. Stocks rip. S&P hits 8,000. Everyone celebrates.

• But fired workers stop spending. Companies weaken. They buy more AI to cut costs. More layoffs. Less spending. A negative feedback loop with no natural brake.

• The top 10% of earners drive 50%+ of all consumer spending. They're the ones getting replaced. A $180K product manager ends up driving Uber for $45K. Multiply that across every major city.

• Ghost GDP emerges - the economy is "growing" on paper, but the money never reaches real people. Productivity is booming. Wages are collapsing.

• Then it hits housing. $13 trillion in mortgages, all underwritten on one assumption: you keep your job for 30 years. In 2008, the loans were bad on day one. In 2028, the loans were good. The world just changed after they were written.

• S&P crashes 38% from highs. Unemployment hits 10.2%. Markets barely react anymore.

• The punchline: you're not reading this in 2028. You're reading it in February 2026. Every domino they describe has already started falling.

61880091

Financial system. I am not asking you to hold those warrants until they are exercised. I am asking you to hold them and sell the warrants when we can realize a substantial profit. Nice quads.

61881477
>>61880091
Interesting. Wouldn't trading the warrants implicitly come with a short term capital gains tax insofar as its impossible to hold them over a year at this point? Would have to be some pretty fair gains to offset that 40% hit...anyways doesn't the warrants increasing in price also imply that the shares have gone up in price as well? I ran some informal modeling estimates using black scholes with iv, roughly .65 years to expiry and this is what I came up with: 15.5 bbby share price = 4.50ish warrant price...25 share price/12ish warrant price...60 share price/45ish warrant price...100 share price/85ish warrant price...200 share price 185ish warrant price...I make no claim as to the veracity of these numbers, just for fun. Anyways what do you see happening to the bbby stock price for these warrants to be worthwhile? Am I thinking on the right track in general?
